problem_statement: Build a complete, production-ready Image to PDF Converter web application using Vue 3 with the Composition API, fully client-side with no backend services required, following modern Vue best practices and clean, maintainable code standards. The app must allow users to upload one or multiple images (JPG, PNG, WEBP), show image previews before conversion, and enable drag-and-drop reordering of images prior to PDF generation, where each image becomes a separate page in the final PDF in the selected order. The user must be able to choose page size (A4, Letter, Auto-fit), orientation (portrait or landscape), image scaling mode (fit, fill, original), and set a custom output filename. The app should display a progress indicator during PDF generation and safely handle large images using compression or resizing via canvas or browser-image-compression. The core engineering challenge is to build a performant, memory-safe, and deterministic conversion engine in Vue 3 that handles the 'Memory vs. Quality' trade-off. The application must process large binary image data (blobs), manage a dynamic reordering state, and perform recursive compression to ensure the resulting PDF is optimized for sharing without exceeding the browser's heap limits or compromising visual integrity. Technical requirements: 100% Client-side with no backend, no API dependencies, no telemetry; use jsPDF for coordinate-based layout and binary PDF construction; reactive ordering system allowing for drag-and-drop re-prioritization of image pages; UI must remain responsive during conversion using requestIdleCallback or async chunking if processing more than 10 images; explicitly reject non-image types and files exceeding 50MB per unit; modular components with TypeScript implementation.
